6. Capsulized dramatization on film or tape following a program

7. Filmstrips or slide collections with synchronized tape com¬
mentary illustrating utilization procedures and results. An
alternate suggestion would b® to supply a script with the slides
or filmstrips for local presentation.
8. Film documentary showing a variety of class activities that
developed from one educational broadcast. This would start
by showing or playing a part or all of the film or tape of the
program stimulating this utilization.
9. Collections of class work resulting from educational broad¬
casts. This could include art, literature, science, music
and similar projects.
10. Complete utilization workshop outlines (short or long) includ¬
ing suggested handouts, sample scripts, time tables, program
examples, etc.
XL. Tape recordings of the discussion within a class following an
educational broadcast.
12. Reprints or recordings on film or tape of selected speechs,
articles in quantity for use with committees and discussion
groups.
This project is being carried out in several phases. The first
step is to find cut what utilization materials now exist, and how they
can be made available through the NAEB. The second step is to develop
kit ideas with local educational groups. These steps would be followed
by screening, production, and distribution phases.
The NAEB Utilization Committee is undertaking to carry out the
first two steps of this plan. The development and distribution steps
will need to be financed from outside of the NAEB. There are several
possibilities for this financing and they will be contacted at the
proper time. The success of this project depends on the cooperation
of schools, educational broadcasting stations and individual NAEB
memberso
